qas.question: Has some states like Arizona embraced their Mexican history?

answers.text: The state (like its southwestern neighbors) has had close linguistic and cultural ties with Mexico
The state outside the Gadsden Purchase of 1853 was part of the New Mexico Territory until 1863, when the western half was made into the Arizona Territory.

qas.question: Has New Mexico had a majority of Spanish speaking natives.

answers.text: The area of the former Gadsden Purchase contained a majority of Spanish-speakers until the 1940s

qas.question: Are Arizona and New Mexico residents speaking Spanish or English?

answers.text: the continuous arrival of Mexican settlers increases the number of Spanish-speakers.

qas.question: Who does the state have territory ties with?

plausible_answers.text: The state outside the Gadsden Purchase of 1853

qas.question: What was part of Mexico territory until 1863?
What area has a the same ratio or anglophones?
What was the eastern half of the New Mexico Territory made into?

context: <a0_0>The state (like its southwestern neighbors) has had close linguistic and cultural ties with <b4_0>Mexico<b4_0/><a0_0/>. <a1_0><b5_0>The state outside the Gadsden Purchase of 1853<b5_0/> was part of the New Mexico Territory until 1863, when the western half was made into the <b7_0>Arizona Territory<b7_0/>.<a1_0/> <a2_0>The area of the former Gadsden Purchase contained a majority of Spanish-speakers until the 1940s<a2_0/>, although the <b6_0>Tucson<b6_0/> area had a higher ratio of anglophones (including Mexican Americans who were fluent in English); <a3_0>the continuous arrival of Mexican settlers increases the number of Spanish-speakers.
